answers.answer: It sounds as if he is having seizures.  He probably does need to go back to the vet since he really needs a complete blood profile, and other blood tests, and urinalysis to ensure that the seizures are not caused by diabetes, for example,  or other metabolic or infectious disease.His heart should also be evaluated, since syncope due to a cardiac cause has a similar presentation as epilepsy.  Syncope is a fainting episode, or partial fainting episode that occurs when not enough oxygen gets to the brain,  due to a heart condition.  Most heart conditions can be controlled very well with heart medications.Epilepsy can also be caused by brain lesions.

question: My cat is an 11 year old tabby who just moved in with me about 10 years ago.  He has never had any health problems until now.  About a week ago she stopped eating and didn't want to go out.  Took him to the vet who didn't have any idea but noticed he was a little tender on his spine, so prescribed him pain killers.  Gave him the pain killers for a couple of days but then he started vomiting so I stopped them and he began to recover on his own.  He came back to his normal hungry self but with more of an appitite.  I guessed this was because he didnt eat anything for a week.  However over the passed couple of days he has had some strange episodes.  I have seen it happen three times now each time when I am feeding him.  He kinda crouches down and looks a bit dazed, his back legs turn to jelly and he just squirms around on the floor for about 1 - 2 minutes, then its over and he is fine.  I have not seen him have these strange episodes at any other time but he spends 50% of his time in the house and 50%  outside. Has anyone else had the same experience, don't no if he needs a vet.  Any advice welcome.
title: Whats happening with my cat?
